comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In April 1894 they were looking for a 'stylish Millener, R.C. and good Saleswoman'' The ad for a dressmaker appeared again in Agust 1894, so presumably the successful applicant in 1892 had moved to pastures new. Still expanding in January 1897 DRESSES; Leonard Bros, Belturbet, require a pushing Salesman, RC, of good appearance and address, for their Dress Department; give full particulars at once. Address 8502, Freeman Office.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the 1901 census, and the OS 25" map, this street is named Butler street. In the earlier 6" map, it is Main street. There are also no bicycles in shot, so I'll guess it's a bit earlier than 1899, maybe 1890? Here is the 1901 census record for Leonard.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The Leonards of Belturbet have a murky past. From the Lancaster Gazette, October 9th, 1841, quoting the Erne Packet: MURDER OF A WIFE BY HER HUSBAND - On Friday last a a man named Leonard, near Belturbet, murdered his wife under the following circumstances: - Some part of the day, while sitting at the fire, he desired her to go out to tie up some corn which was cut, and she, being at the time busily engaged at some household employment, did not go out immediately, on which, without any provocation, he took up an iron candlestick used for holding burning rushes, and coming behind her where she stooped, gave her two or three blows on the back of the head, which killed her on the spot. The coroner's jury returned a verdict of wilful murder against him, and he was accordingly lodged in our gaol on Saturday. The wretched man did not deny the act, nor did he assign any reason. He is about 60 years of age, and was 21 years married; this woman was his second wife; and it did not appear that they had ever lived on bad terms. It is considered he committed the deed under the influence of temporary insanity.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Can you remember the date ranges for the OSI historic maps (for Main Street vs. Butler Street)? And that very definitely looks like a Red Hand outside Strain's!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Crikey, what a story! Wonder if they were country Leonards, as opposed to the town Leonards? It always interests me how people think that murder/manslaughter is a modern phenomenon, and that the world has gone to hell in a handbasket. Go through any old newspapers and you find reports like this...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I think your suspicions are confirmed. Strains only seem to advertise for staff in the Belfast News-Letter. This on Dec 29th 1898: SPIRIT COUNTER - Wanted, a Young Man, Protestant, for the above business; enclose reference, lowest salary, &c; also a well-educated Lad as an Apprentice to General Grocery and Hardware. - Apply Strain & Thompson, Belturbet In July 1894 they specified 'an Intelligent young Man, of sober habits, as Assistant to Grocery and Spirit business'. Presumably they didn't want staff tempted to take a crafty tipple from the stock.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
The OS 25" maps date from 1888-1913, but most are closer to 1900, I think.

The 6" maps (which show Main Street) date from 1837 to 42.

Of course, just because the street was officially named Butler Street for a while doesn't mean that the photographer recorded it as Butler Street.

comment._content: Hamilton's Irish House is now the Seven Horseshoes Hotel and Bar.

Sheet Name Surveyed    Published
CN011-13  01/Jun/1910 01/Jun/1910

I think it's in there, getting it out is the problem...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: All right class, now pay attention, I'm only going to say this once: 1. Go to the OS historical map you are interested in here 2. Click the Search button at top right. 3. Select the Historic tab. You are asked for the Map Sheet Name. Enter DN018, the example given, and click Search. 4. The map behind turns green, and the sheet numbers are shown. Now enter the sheet number for the spot you are interested in, here CN011-13, and hit Search. 5. The dates for that sheet are shown, 1st of June 1910. I tested this using Firefox, IE might behave differently. Off to test this method on the Rotunda tennis courts...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thanks for that. Now I know that these OS links do not work for Google Chrome (in Australia) for some reason - Oh Shot! IE and Firefox seem fine. Street view in Chrome is a bit iffy sometimes too . Perhaps a word to the Great God of Google ... or the Great Gid if Giggle.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I agree about murder/mayhem not being a modern phenomenon. There were some particularly violent sporting encounters. Here's an acccount of Belturbet v Monaghan rugby match in October 1896. Those Monaghan men who were left standing walked off in protest following the 'lively doings'. Edit: on reflection, this piece was included in a Worcester newspaper, probably as a bit of sensationalism, to fill up some column inches, and no doubt confirm prejudices about the uncivilised Irish (the headline hints at this). Having said that, my impression is that there was more violence at football (of whatever sort) matches then than now. It certainly didn't start in the 1970s.

comment.author: 94819917@N00
comment._content: I find it interesting that while so much has changed, many of the buildings endure. Leonards / Gers Coffee Stop is now the Diamond Cafe, but they are all in the same lovely old stone building. The edifice on the left, closer to the viewer was a food store in the ca. 1990 shot, but is now Gilbride's Landis (sp?) Foodstore, according to Giggle Mops Google Maps (oh, thanks, @beachcomberaustralia!), alongside Curry's Diamond Bar. Next to the odd windlass machine @blackpoolbeach mentions now stands the 'new' Post Office (built in nineteen-ought-four A.D.).
